utterances: It sloshes around a lot.
Yeah - and yeah.
Let's go to number three.
What happened with number three?
So number three - number three would have worked if we had kept the same first stage engine as flight two.
But we upgraded the engine because we wanted to use the engine on flight three that we planned to use in our big vehicle, Falcon 9, and get flight history on that before using it on our big vehicle.
And unfortunately, the thrust transient, which is for - during shutdown, which is basically the rate at which the thrust- how the thrust decays over time.
It was a much longer thrust decay than the old engine.
And so after we separated the stages, the first stage actually still had residual thrust and basically kept on going forward and rear-ended the second stage.
I hate it when that happens.
Right.
Yeah, (unintelligible).
No kidding.
So you fixed that through that for number four.
We've basically made a very small timing change to basically extend the time from when we initiate managing cut off, to second stage, to the stage of separation.
We just increased that by a few seconds, and solved the problem, then we got through all of it.
Yeah.
So for all those people who thought they couldn't understand rocket science, there it is.
And it's just about a minute and a half.
I got about 30 seconds left.
Elon, where do you go next?
Well, we have a bunch of exciting things happening with Falcon 9.
We're going to have Falcon 9 at Cape Canaveral in December and we hope to do our first launch around the middle of this year.
And then followed shortly by our first launch for NASA, which will be a test flight of our Dragon Spacecraft.
So that's going to be very exciting.
I think, you know, the SpaceX is really going to make a big difference to the space program and make sure we're not reliant on the Russians after 2010.
We'll see you at the Cape.
All right.
Elon Musk, who is the founder of SpaceX and the company's CEO and CTO.
Thanks for taking time to be with us today.
Good luck to you.
Thank you.
We're going to take a short break.
Come back, change gears one more time and talk about - well, things that appear to be what they are, but they're not really.
See, you don't even appear to know what I'm talking about.
But you'll find out more after this break.
So stay with us.
We'll be right back.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
American movies and American gangsters grew up together.
In the '30s, audiences were riveted by fast-talking tough guy, Jimmy Cagney, in ""The Public Enemy.
(Soundbite of film ""The Public Enemy"")
(As Steve) Please, you ain't going to slug me, are you?
Roland Martin, it's clear that the White House is going to - and Republicans are going to adopt this strategy, cloak all of this with the idea as a central campaign issue for November.
We heard advisor Karl Rove state very clearly this week that that's what should be done.
What of the point that maybe liberals do have this all wrong.
Maybe middle America is saying, look, I'm willing to give up civil liberties.
If I'm not doing anything wrong, as long as you're, perhaps, not peeking in my bedroom, you want to tap my phone for a minute, go ahead.
Well, I think the problem here is that liberals don't know how to construct a proper argument to rebut the President.
The key for them, I think, in this case is to say, look, Mr. President, this is the law.
This is what it says.
You have the right to eavesdrop, and you have up to 72 hours to get a warrant.
And so when he says, oh, I didn't break the law, you know, we informed everyone, he's shading up the actual facts.
And so as long as they don't know how to articulate a proper argument, they're going to lose.
And so Karl Rove is sending a signal again.
It is going to be about security.
In 2004 he said it is going to be about terrorism.
The Democrats continue to be weak on this particular issue.
They cannot articulate properly, and so they're going to have a tough time unless they are able to come up with some kind of message that can indeed resonate with the American people.
And this...
And they have.

But Roland, they have, of course, a tough job to do, the Democrats because first of all, they don't control any of the branches of the government, so they have no platform, and when they control all the branches of the government, you can orchestrate events, as we see on everything, not just this.
That's the first problem.

Yeah, but you know what, Mary, that being said, it seems to me this White House may have been able to supersede all of the problems that they've had, avoid them, if you will, had they just gone to Congress beforehand, sat down with leadership on both sides of the aisle, said, look gentleman and ladies, this is what we need to do to keep this country safe.
This is what I'm looking at.
If you do the preemptive strike sometimes in Washington, as you well know, you don't have to face the same headaches.
But Ed...
But that's not what they want to do, though.
What we're missing here is that that's not what they want to do.
What they want to do...
I know it's not what they want to do.
Is to force--what they want to do is not to consult with anybody else.
Absolutely
And not consult in a bipartisan way.
They want to make the Democrats appear to be people who are weak on war, and the way you do that is keep heightened the contradictions, heightened the issues.
You don't have a cooperation stance, you have a fighting stance.
And reframe it later.
And that's what they want to do
All right, let's move to something else that some suggest the Democrats are missing the boat on in terms of just being able to articulate it as Roland suggests.
And Roland, pick up on this if you will, and that is of course the fight for Judge Alito, his nomination to the Supreme Court.
The first step is passed.
Today it seems that the judiciary committee will give its okay, probably along party lines here, to say that the nomination go to full Senate.
It does not look as though Democrats are going to muster up enough courage, if you will, or even see the sense in filibustering, something that many people see as just inevitable.
Well, I think they boxed themselves in initially by coming out - yeah, several people who came out when he was first nominated, talked about how great of a person he was and how qualified he was.
And see, they continue to use this barometer of if you went to Harvard, you went to Yale, you were a prosecutor, oh, the ABA gives you great marks.
Well, you're a qualified candidate.
And so that somehow allows you to overlook his views on so many different issues.

I mean, anybody can see that the man is a flaming conservative, and so for him to sit there in the hearings and to basically deny the last 15, 20 years is simply a creative lie by a Supreme Court nominee, and that's simply what it is.
But Roland, but there's nothing wrong with him being a conservative, and I don't think that's where the Democrats make their mistakes.
No, no. I have no problem with that.
No, no. I have no problem with that.
I think...
But don't sit there and tell me I'm really not.
I sort of felt that way 15 years ago, but I have an open mind today.
Right.
Yeah.
Well, but see, that's a different issue.
I think whether--the Democrats--well, let's - let me not pursue it in that context, just saying it's the Democrats who have losses.
The American people voted for this President.

He has nominated Sam Alito, and now what we have is a candidate who went before the judiciary committee and who was a very technical judge, a man who could explain himself, who could explain away everything.
In fact, I remember--if I am not mistaken--there was on question where he could legally--he was unable to explain technically why it might be unconstitutional to execute an innocent person.
I mean what I found distressing about the complete hearings is that, you know of the 500 questions that were answered; there was no illumination on anything.
This was basically just a technical, a technical display of legal judicial philosophy.
The hearings are a joke.
We all agree on that, we talked about that last week.
But Mary, here's the question Roland brings up that's interesting, the idea that, you elected a man who has run on a conservative platform.
You knew what you were going to get from Bush.
And the idea that Democrats continue to say, to use Roland's verbiage that, these people are flaming conservatives.
Well, okay of course they are, that's not enough to keep you off the court frankly.
Right.
We are.
What the Democrats need to learn how to do is to fight and not be afraid to fight with bare knuckles like the Republicans do.
This all started with the 2000 election when they didn't fight and Bush was given the election by the Supreme Court.
And, they didn't fight, starting from Al Gore all the way down, even though they had a basis for fighting, to show that they had some guts.
And the Republicans learned that they don't have any guts, they don't fight on anything.
So of course, he gets re-elected in 2004 because you know, once you're elected it's hard not to get re-elected, unless you're his father.
But in any case, then the next thing that happens is, on these issues, they don't fight.
They caved in on the filibuster, gave it away, which was the only thing that they had, and got up in public and tried to make it sound like they weren't giving it away.
That's because the Democratic Party internally is divided between those who want to fight and those who see that, they ought to make themselves appear to be different or not.
So, the Alito outcome is a result of that non-fighting stance, which has prevailed.
And what I'm worried about, everybody keeps talking about abortion, I'm worried about the race cases.
I'm worried about the Michigan case, which was five to four and Justice Kennedy didn't vote on that.
Yeah, barely squeaked through.
Yeah, the affirmative action question there.
I mean he voted on cases the other way.
I'm worried about all these things.
But the Democrats have to learn how to fight.
Let me note this that, it could in fact, go to the full Senate vote as early as this week.
Let us turn our attention to a movie that's raising a lot of eyebrows at the Sundance Film Festival, and a lot of other places.
It's a movie called Son of Man.
It portrays Christ as a modern, African revolutionary.
And, what's interesting here is that the aim the filmmakers say is to shatter the Western image of the Savior with fair hair and blue eyes.
Now, Nat, you know religion and politics, we've already jumped in the pool with politics, we might as well with religion.

When you look at the traditional image of Jesus and you see what this movie, and others before it, have tried to do, is there a need really, today, to revisit the image of Jesus and what Western society has portrayed this man to be, physically?
Oh, I think there is always.
And there is a constant... Well let me put it this way; there is always a struggle within the faith community to re-examine the message of Christ and I think even more so today than ever before.
And that this film is representative of new communities have technology and having a story, and being able to put the story of Jesus in their context.

I think it, you know right here at home we're looking at, I think it's an NBC Series, The Book of Daniel in which, the American Family Counsel is outraged by the portrayal of Jesus as being sort of a-I've seen a couple of installments.
I don't think this Jesus has blue eyes, but he is a sort of a modern, contemporary figure who is very passive and who sort of offers these kind of non-controversial judgments.
So, I think the-the idea that now we have a filmmaker who has cast Jesus in context with South Africa, or at least Africa I don't know if it's necessarily South Africa.
Yeah, Roland, always interesting to see, when you go to your grandma or your auntie's house, to see Jesus lookin' like on the Beatles in the mid-70s.
What of the thought of putting a new face on him?
